IndustryType: Production and storage of pesticides, biocides, fungicides

Title: Loss of 1,2- Dibromoethane (Ethylene dibromide)
LessonsLearned: <p>&nbsp;<span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">The main causes for the&nbsp;failure were around the loss of compression on the joint faces and the subsequent displacement of the gasket. The most likely causes were; <br></span><br></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">1) The use of bolts / studs with different tensile strength causing uneven stretching of the bolts in the flange joint;<br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">2) The machined surface finish on the safety valve flange face is not to the correct specification;<br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">3) External loading on the joint caused by unsupported pipe work;<br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt"><span style="font-size: small">4) Inherent vibration in the Schenk.</span></span></p>
EmergencyResponce_Descr: <font size="2"><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial">Spill contained within site drains.</span> </font><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="2">Effluent diverted to emergency containment tanks.</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="2">Some effluent sent offsite in error - no breach of consent levels at water company.</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="2">Clean up undertaken with boots, helmet,&nbsp;pvc gloves and safety glasses and carbon mask.</font></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font size="2">RAE meter used for detecting levels of EDB.</font></span>

Reasons.ItemDescription: Substances involved: greater than 5% of quantity in Column 3 of Annex I
Injury to persons: >= 1 fatalities, >= 6 hospitalizing injuries etc.
Immediate damage to the environment (according to Annex VI)

AccidentDescription: <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font size="2"><font>Due to the failure of a joint on a Schenk filter, there was a release of a significant quantity (approximately 5 tonnes) of material, known as Quatmass Extraction Solution. This material contained Reglone, and approximately 2 tonnes of Ethylene Dibromide, both of which are toxic. <br></font><br>A batch of Reglone product was being manufactured and had reached the filtration stage. Production had been normal up to this point.&nbsp;&nbsp;The batch&nbsp;was sent from the reactor vessel to the Schenk filter under 6 barg pressure, and the usual sequence is that when the vessel is empty the pressure drops and the pressure indicator in the Schenk filter senses this and sends a message to the process control computer to open the nitrogen valve. The nitrogen is then introduced under pressure to drive the filtration.</font><br><br><font size="2">On this occasion the automated nitrogen valve opened, but the nitrogen pressure did not rise&nbsp;above 2 barg, and a message was sent to the process control computer stating 'Pressure slow in rising'. The operator did not notice this for&nbsp;about 45 minutes due to other duties.&nbsp;&nbsp;It was not an alarm.<br></font><br><font size="2">When the operator&nbsp;saw the message, he sent another operator out to investigate, and he saw that there had been a loss of containment and the batch material had been released through the flange connected to the pressure relief valve. It ran down the side of the vessel, through the lagging and into the site drains.<br><br>The gasket was protruding through the side of the flange and it is thought it had been blown out when the nitrogen was put on to the filter unit.<br></font><br><font size="2">The joint had been broken at the shutdown about 6 months previously, but the unit had been in operation</font> <font size="2">since then handling around 20 batches per week. The filter unit, and a second&nbsp;identical one, were installed 20 years ago.<br><br></font></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="2">The main causes for the&nbsp;failure were around the loss of compression on the joint faces and the subsequent displacement of the gasket. The most likely causes were; <br></font><br></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="2">1) The use of bolts / studs with different tensile strength causing uneven stretching of the bolts in the flange joint;<br></font></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="2">2) The machined surface finish on the safety valve flange face is not to the correct specification;<br></font></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="2">3) External loading on the joint caused by unsupported pipe work;<br></font></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font size="2">4) Inherent vibration in the Schenk.<br></font><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="3"><br></font><font size="2"><font>The most significant deficiency was considered to be inadequate floor and filter mountings.</font></font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 12pt"><font size="2">Carcinogenic material (EDB) released from the filter and collected in the site drains<span>.<span> </span>It was subsequently diverted to the site emergency containment tanks</span>.<span> </span>Due to errors causing delays at the site effluent treatment plant, some effluent was sent to Yorkshire Water, rather than kept on site.<span> </span>Yorkshire Water has since verbally confirmed their samples showed no indication of a consent breach.<br><br>Remedial action taken: <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font size="3"></font></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>Repairs were carried out to support the Schenk filter and improvements made to flange integrity.<span> </span>Further work was undertaken to investigate vibration as a direct result of operational procedures (such as the backwash procedure which was highlighted as being different to what the filtration consultant expected).</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>&nbsp;</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>Root Cause Analysis undertaken by Syngenta identified a number of further<span> </span>operational and engineering improvements.<span> </span>These were implemented during plant outages in October and November 2010 and included:</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>- Redesign of the filter backwash system</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>- Installation of pressure differential instruments to monitor filter performance</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>- Installation of two accelerometers which continuously monitor vibration and will trip the filter spin sequence at predetermined levels. </font></span><span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>- Filter refurbishment</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>&nbsp;</font></span> <span style="FONT-FAMILY: Arial"><font>To ensure the equipment is maintained to standard additional engineering routines have been introduced including specific checks of the support legs &amp; plinths, joint integrity and bolt torque.</font></span> <br><font></font></font></span></span></span>

Site_Description: Syngenta are a Swiss owned company, and they carry out batch&nbsp;manufacture of&nbsp;herbicides and pesticides on this site. The site is one of the&nbsp;legacy ICI sites. They are a COMAH top tier site and have consent for various chemicals including&nbsp;highly flammables, flammables, very toxics, toxics, oxidising, dangerous to the environment, other classification (R14) and named substances including chlorine.&nbsp;
Installation_Description: &nbsp;This unit makes Reglone as part of a multi-stage batch process. The control room is not manned continuously, although the unit runs 24 hours per day on a shift system.

Causes_Description: <p>&nbsp;<span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">The main causes for the&nbsp;failure were around the loss of compression on the joint faces and the subsequent displacement of the gasket. The most likely causes were; <br></span><br></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">1) The use of bolts / studs with different tensile strength causing uneven stretching of the bolts in the flange joint;<br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">2) The machined surface finish on the safety valve flange face is not to the correct specification;<br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: small">3) External loading on the joint caused by unsupported pipe work;<br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt"><span style="font-size: small">4) Inherent vibration in the Schenk.<br></span></span></p>
